segments.text: Tell me about your first job with 143rd Infantry.
Where were you stationed?
Where were they sent you?
Well, upon mobilization, initially we stayed at home station because, you know, the camps weren't ready.
And that program then was to bring the National Guard in for one year.
one year only.
In other words, that was just to get them and train them in readiness in the event that it would be needed.
And after about, oh, I guess a month, we went to Camp Bui at Brownwood.
We lived in tents with very comfortable tents.
They had a concrete slab, you know, and there was a tent frame.
And we had gas.
so in the morning all you had to do with the pilot line was just pull that lever.
Somebody nearest had a string of wire tied to it so it was warm when you got out of bed.
And we trained there.
And didn't have fatigues, it didn't wear fatigues.
That becomes a really rather vivid in my memory because we were wearing
Those days, you know, we had pinks and greens, pink trousers and green jackets.
And we were wearing those pinks out on the field to train with.
And of course, around Brownwood, this thing right here, you got all sorts of thorns.
And it picked that fabric to where it all started, ruined it, in other words.
So everybody ruined their uniform, so they had to buy a new uniform, another uniform.
Another interesting thing that happened
He did have post-exchanges at that time, but Lauderstein, San Antonio Lauderstein, he provided the post-exchange facility.
It sold uniform.
So, you know, he had nothing to do with these thornages.
He really had a big business of selling all this.
And they expensive.
Then they went through this situation of should you have long beaver coats or short beaver coats.
So we were ordered all to buy long beaver coats.
Everybody had to buy a long beaver coat, and they were very expensive.
So just the uniforms were a problem back in 1940.
Yeah.
And the U.S. government couldn't supply all the troops, in other words.
No.
Oh, no.
They were short both clothing and certainly equipment.
Oh, sure.
Because there's many pictures and articles written about it.
In the first Louisiana maneuver, active mobilization, we went to Leesville, Louisiana area.
And you had sticks that represented mortars and logs that represented artillery.
And even some didn't even have rifles.
They were carrying a wooden replica of a rifle.
And you should have plenty of rifles from World War I, though, with those old MPOs or old .
Your basic mission in the 143rd was training, is that right?
That's right, readiness training.
And to get equipment and get trained, but mainly to get the people away from home and in the field.
And later on, of course, we hadn't got field uniforms.
When we were first there, the only uniform we were wearing was what you'd call a dress uniform.
Not a few in the report.
Now during this time, 1940, you went to the company officer's course at Fort Benning, Georgia.
Yeah.
And tell me about that.
How long was it?
What was the curriculum?
As I recall, it was just short of three months.
And the purpose of that course, now presently, a graduate ROTC, a graduate military captain, they go to a similar course.
It's a basic officer's course.
where that you, once again, you're taught map reading and weapons training.
That's right.
Very similar to Officer Candidate School.
It's, of course, Officer Candidate School.
You've got to go a little bit farther because they come really as recruits.
Some of them had some military training, but very little.
But it was that type of training, basic officer's course, basic such.
But it was very helpful and very
a requirement because you had to remember a particular National Guard.
Many National Guard officers were appointed in those days.
And what training they had was in the armor.
And you just, who trained them?
Who has the time?
Who has the knowledge?
So this, of course, was very necessary.
particularly for the National Guard officers and also reserve officers, of course, who had been called active duty in a recent drive to the bar of TC.
And they were from all over the United States.
It was a very interesting course.
And two later on, several of the divisions went to the Far East and, of course, others went to Europe.
Now, at this time, of course, the Japanese in 1940 were fighting the Chinese since 1937.
And on the other side of the world, the Germans were fighting the English at this time.
It was about the time of the Battle of Britain.
Did you think that the United States would soon be in war?
Well, I think everyone couldn't help but
think the way things were going would probably be in it.
But the nation didn't think so.
And one reason why the nation didn't is because Roosevelt kept saying, you know, that we're not going to send our boys to somebody else's war.
And because they've been called back to duty for a year, the National Guard, their favorite song that day is Goodbye, Dear.
I'll be back in a year.
I'm in the Army now.
Well, just before the year was over, Congress voted
by one vote, carried by one vote, to continue the National Guard on active duty, even though it was just a short time before Pearl Harbor.
Oh, were you happy that it was going to stay on National Guard and you weren't going to be placed back on a reserve status?
Oh, yeah.
You wanted to stay on active duty.
Just like after we got involved in the war, I wanted to go to Europe.
Well, let's talk about that.
What happened?
You're training all the way up until December 7, 1941.
Do you remember where you were when you heard the news of Pearl Harbor?
Yeah.
Cameron, Texas.
I was having a date with my school teacher's wife to be.
What was your reaction?
Well, we had a, or at least I had, we were married in a new red Ford convertible.
out Sunday, taking a ride.
Of course, we were notified to return to base.
Well, I would have returned anyway because anybody knows.
Because they were pretty well over the radio then.
They announced that it's been heavy casualties and damage has been great, but
no assessment really has been made yet.
So it wasn't a case of trying to keep it quiet how much damage was done.
Of course, no need to, because the Japanese did it and saw them sinking and knew what had happened, knew the extent of the damage.
So we went back and stayed in Camp Boyd.
But then people on the West Coast got reporting that subs had been sighted.
And the West Coast particularly felt, and this is what led up to what occurred with the evacuation of the Japanese, you know, and put them in relocation camp.
So they were really hysterical.
All up and down the Coast Coast, they thought the Japanese would invade at any time.
And that's when they thought somebody was sending messages and receiving and told the innocent were suspect.
So it was just a general evacuation.
Also, at Freeport, Dow Chemical, they felt that they were exposed, and they were making the critical metals that we needed to build all these aircraft we were in the process of building.
So we knew they had to protect Dow Chemical.
So our company, E Company 143rd Infantry, we were alerted at night.
to move by convoy to Freeport to protect Dow Chemical.

And now you think of it, it sounds kind of oozy asinine to think you go get, say, 150 or 200 infantrymen with rifles, machine guns, to go to protect a chemical plant that's right on the edge of the Gulf, you know, that you service.
You could use a cannon, a larger artillery to destroy it.
But they were more concerned about sabotage, you know, because submarines, they'd seen submarines in the Gulf.
I don't know if they actually saw them or not.
Did you ever, you never saw a submarine in the Gulf, did you?
And did you ever have any sabotage at all in the area of Freeport?
Nice tour of duty there, because that's a beautiful place there on the Gulf, isn't it?
And they had a nice facility.
It was a big building.
I guess at one time, that must have been a district, a transit type of thing, because they had beds in there that were very comfortable.
Of course, we were on patrol, at least about a third of us at all times, up and down the coastline.
So we returned after the scare receded.
Then we moved to Camp Blanding, Florida.
And the purpose of going to Camp Blanding was to take further training, of course, and to prepare for an overseas ship.
It's actually Pearl Harbor now.
And we trained there with the 1st Division, with the Corps.
And after several months there, and our troops didn't like that because we moved into tents there.
But there, they were coal-burning stoves in the whole area, burning coal.
You got cinders and all that.
And you had to get up and build a fire, and you missed that nice, clean, natural gas.
We stayed there for several months.
And did you know where you were headed?
You said you were preparing for overseas, but you had no idea.
No, no.
Then while I was there in the landing, in my job then, I was the headquarters company commander in the S2 wearing two hats.
We had a quota to go to Brooksfield, Texas to an aerial observation course.
And the plan at that time was that
Of course, the Air Force wasn't Air Force.
It was Air Corps.
It was part of the Army .

That if we had a mission to accomplish, and we wanted to get intelligence, information, this trained individual would go out to the airstrip, and getting the back seat of an aircraft flown by the air, and telling what the mission was, and even plan it, navigate it.
And we'd go out, take pictures, whatever the mission was, and then return to base.
In other words, the person on the ground that knew what he wanted was trained to go up and sit in a plane and accomplish it.
And so that's what I was down at Brookfield, which is very interesting.
In addition to aerial photography, navigation, flexible machine gun, you're also trained to
to adjust artillery using code CW.
So you had to be a radio operator and all sorts of things.
So that was what that course was about.
And it's very interesting, although sometimes it can be kind of hairy on the flights.
We also had night flights.
Because the pilots of these planes, and they were 052s, heavy.
underpowered as far as the Indians concerned.
It was really a Navy plane.
The landing gear retracted up into the fuselage.
In fact, there's one down there near Houston, the side of the road now that's been there all this year.
It's part of a tavern or something.
I think they call it the ship or the airship.
Because we lost quite a few.
They get lost and run out of fuel.
And fortunately, mine didn't.
although we ground looped on takeoff one time.
Anyway, but these pilots were just out of flying school.
They didn't like the plane either.
They didn't have much confidence in themselves, particularly in the plane.
And at night, another thing at that time, you took off on one frequency, and as soon as you got airborne, then you had to retune your radio to a ground station.
away from the field.
Daytime is no problem, but at nighttime with an inexperienced pilot, and we had several that went to Mexico, got lost and went to Raleigh, and of course had to bail out, for sure.
So at night, I never did even retune.
I kept it on our station.
And of course, I made a low mark on my communication with the base station down below.
Because I wasn't about to get up there and not be able to get back to the ground.
But the main reason, it wasn't because of the retuning.
That was simple, although they didn't have push buttons.
You had to get down there and turn this thing and get it just at the right setting.
At night, while you're down and you plan your navigation course on time, distance on headings and time,
I didn't want to be down and not observing for that pilot, because he might get disoriented or something in mid.
I was flying at night with the lights.
You know, you fly at night, you know, you pick as you plan it all, you know where everything is.
And we got back each time.
Another problem they had on landing, though, the aircraft, you had to crank down an antenna that had a great big, well, it was about the size of that,
lead, you crank that down.
But you'd have to remember to crank that thing up before you land it, because if not, boy, you'd hang it on wires and people's heads and so forth.
And a lot of them would forget to reel up their antenna.
Another common, of course, mistake was made is that they'd forget to take the cover over the camera.
They'd go out and
fly all this nation back and forth, you know, make these strips, come back and find out.
All they took was a picture of the cover.
But returned back, and when I got back to Camp Blanning, I said, where's the unit?
They said, Carolina on maneuvers.
I said, well, I better join them.
And this colonel, he said, no, Lieutenant, we're really happy to see you because I need you to help me here.
So we got the inventory of all this equipment, turned it over to the post,
Then we got a load of trains with the things we were taking with us, you know, from day rooms like radios and that sort of thing, up to Camp Edwards.
That was the home station, which people were in the field, but that's where they were going.
And this was really something to leave your home station to go on a maneuver and then never return there and go from there.
Sure.
It was all that unfinished business that's got to be accomplished in the back.
So I said, okay, he's the boss.
So I worked there for several days.
Finally we got the train loaded and I was going to command.
And we went on up to Massachusetts to Camp Edwards on the Cape.
And I noticed that the regimental commander that met the train, first he looked at me kind of astounded.
And he spoke to me, returned my salute.
And then turned and stalked off.
What's happening?
And time went on, and I didn't find out until after the war.
In the book we have here now, The Texas Army, have you ever seen that book?
I read in there that when I didn't return directly from
Brooksfield.
They dropped me as being absent without leave.
And they had called Brooksfield.
They said, well, he signed out right here on this date.
Boy, he should have been there long ago.
Days have passed now.
Nobody thought to call down there, Camp Blanning, and find out whether Andrews was there.
So they all thought that you were over the hill?
Yeah, desertion.
And in the book, he writes about that, he doesn't name me, but he writes about this lieutenant, was the first one that deserted, was AWL.
Of course, they're going to drop me after 30 days for desertion.
They're planning on it.
So they had met at division and said, well, we've got to make an example of this one officer.
So we're going to get him the maximum.
As soon as we get him, we're going to try him.
So that's what shocked Colonel Martin when he found out.
And I imagine immediately he said, well, guys, that guy's been down there all the time.
He goes, he was in command of the train and brought it up here from Camp Blanning.
And what had happened, this is what petty personalities can do.
The colonel who was down at Blanning was a regular Army colonel who
if not an alcoholic, boarded on the alcoholic scene.
He and the division had been at odds, so they kind of banished him down there to keep him out of everybody else's way.
So that's one reason they didn't call.
They wouldn't pay any attention to him.
But it turned out I was never tried, and nobody ever even said I was going to be, nor did they apologize.
I mean, just went on.
It took an actual war that I talked to some people and then saw this Texas book.
Texas Army.
So at Blanding, our purpose at Blanding at Edwards was amphibious training.
That was a big amphibious training center.
And you were getting ready for landing.
Now we had our families along with us.
Of course, not paid, not like it is now when you have to change the station.
At your own expense, actually, it's got to find places to live.
And in most, each of these places, planning out, Edward, we were busy working at night, working day to day.
I would think so.
We didn't see our family very much at all.
You were still, your mission was training.
Yeah.
And so the day finally arrived, actually, I call that amphibious training we had.
And we were going to ship out, although they didn't know where we went.
So the family started back to Texas.
We loaded in and went to Brooklyn to load on the ship.
When was this?
Early 43?
Yeah.
It was one day before our anniversary, so that was on the 2nd of April, 43.
We loaded onto a Hawaiian shipper.
That's a converted Hawaiian pineapple boat.
Pretty crowded.
And then joined a convoy.
Oh, it was a big convoy.
Everything had to be convoyed.
That was the height of the German submarines.
Particularly against the British, boy, they were giving them a beating up in the North Sea.
It was a big convoy.
I guess we had 15 or 20 cargo ships like ours and Navy.
I don't forget how many you could see all the destroyers around us.
It landed in North Africa, near Oran.
Where is that?
Algeria?
Oran?
Oran or Algeria?
Algeria.
O-R-A-N. Yeah, O-R-A-N. Algeria.
Okay, so you landed there and probably in that same month, April 1943.
And a ship, our convoy, not ours, we landed with, and wasn't even aware of it.
It was one of the ships in the convoy that got into the Mediterranean.
was hit by a submarine and loaded with troops.
But it wasn't in the 36th Division.
Did they lose many troops?
I don't know how many they lost.
I don't think they lost a great number.
I mean, not like two or three hundred, but they lost quite a few.
What was the feeling of the men when you landed?
Were people eager to get in the war or were they nervous or anxious?
Do you remember their feelings and your feelings?
Most were agents.
They've described, you know, after Vietnam, World War II being a popular war.
That's because everybody was involved.
Their families and every family had somebody somewhere.
And patriotism, too.
Everybody was eager to do their share.
There's nothing to compare it with Vietnam.
Vietnam's a tragedy, disaster from the word go.
Well, we get back to this travel log.
And when we landed, then we moved on out a short distance outside of Oren.
And it was night, so we pitched pup tents.
And everyone, gosh, this terrible odor that we all smelled.
And when daylight arrived, the Arabs were standing around there.
trying to figure out what we were doing, bivouacking in their latrine.
You know, not having any toilet, not even slitting, you know, this was the area out there where they relieved themselves.
And so at night, how you lined up the tent, you know, you just went down and pitched the tent.
Gosh, it was terrible.
Well, the next day after that, trucks came and we moved over towards the
to French Maraca near Rabat.
There's Rabat right there.
See Rabat?
R-A-B-A-T.
I said truck, weren't truck, were train.
R-A-B-A-T. Why did you move?
In that way, when the war is going the other way.
Yeah, when the war was going east.
Spanish-Morocco.
Spain, you know, was not friendly at all, and they expected Spanish-Morocco to be a problem
And so they moved the 36th Division over here into French Maraca in case it... To control the straits.
Control, yeah, to be there in the... Straits of Gibraltar.
And so we've been whacked in a cork forest, cork tree.
But that trip was not with truck, it was by train.
Old World War I type trains where they used to call them 40 and 8, you know, 40 men or 8 animals, 40 at that time.
chugging along clear across that desert-like terrain.
So we stayed there and we also protected, you know remember they had a head to state meeting at Casablanca.
Yeah.
Well.
And did you go to Casablanca for that?
Our, our trip, our troops provided the security for this big, big castle.
I wouldn't call it a castle, just a great big mansion.
Did you get to see either Roosevelt or Churchill?
No.
We provided security in the distance.
We had no business to go into.
I didn't have any business.
I didn't see them.
Was there a lot of worry about sabotage?
Or was it a secure area?
It was a secure area.
What were the conditions like in Morocco?
Well, of course, Morocco had never been touched with a war.
So everything was business as usual.
There were some ships.
You remember the French?
When the French surrendered, they ordered their navy
to run aground, including cargo ships.
And there was a ship near Rabat that was aground, a great big ship.
Of course, we were eating canned food.
And the captain was aboard.
I don't remember what his cargo was.
Cargo was intact.
And he could eventually get off.
He couldn't by himself.
He would have to have tugs and things to pull him up.
But he had a whole locker full of meat, fresh meat.
So he'd have us aboard.
He had some good wine, so we had a good steak.
So military life in Morocco was pretty good during the war.
Yeah, actually, see, most of the troops
Well, they had the palace guard, that type of thing, but that's the reason we were there to provide troops.
No, you get on the west side of Africa, there's very little activity of the war at all.
Did you want to get back to the east side and to participate in the invasion of Sicily?
Yeah, because we were all busy there.
training.
We were training where you just weren't sitting around there.
But we knew and we had observers by the way that went up to the front and returned so we got all of the gory details of how the fighting was going there.
Then while we were there also we started taking these German prisoners.
You know after the Germans finally lost and evacuated but most of them
captured.
And our troops provided the truck to haul the Germans, and we had to guard way, you know, clear across over where they were.
We were hundreds of thousands of miles, really.
So they had to haul them all the way back to Oren, that big enclosure.
And our troops would get so tired,
This makes you wonder why we even have wars when things like this occur.
But the Germans, who were regarded and felt sorry for him, they said, you go ahead and get some sleep so I'll guard for you.
No kidding.
But the truth of the matter is that they didn't try to escape because there's nowhere you can escape.
You can't go out in that desert and die.
So you'd actually end up with more troops than you started out with.
Because you'd pick up stragglers, some who got off the truck to relieve themselves or something.
And of course, all the German troops were, boy, they were good-looking troops.
Big, husky, many of them blonde and blue-eyed and tip-top physical condition.
Good equipment.
Just when there's prisoners, just as if they were right.
In other words, the command structure
Of course, you're usually a prison camp.
You're trying to separate your senior people from them because of that.
But even down in the lowest squad and so forth, that sergeant had them under control.
Every morning in the enclosure, get up and take calisthenics together.
Everything was done, precision.
And so some of our troops.
How about the Italian troops?
Did you capture any Italians?
At least they didn't come back to us.
See, these were coming to be shipped back to the United States, which we did.
A lot of them down in Fort Benning.
A lot of them around here in Texas.
So we finished the training there in North Africa and being in French Morocco.
Then we thought that we were going into
Sicily, although, of course, we didn't know where we were going.
We thought we were going somewhere.
Because the North African campaign had come to a conclusion.
But anybody looking at the map would think it would be Sicily or Italy.
Of course, it could have been southern France, but it wasn't at the time.
So we went to finally load it on ship.
not for Sicily because other units had gotten into Sicily, landed.
So we didn't know where we were going.
Were we going to reinforce Sicily?
We didn't think so because it just about cleaned up there.
But it turned out that we were going to Italy.
And it was all the leaders,
went to be briefed, which we were, about going in Salerno.
I said, now, keep this on.
I don't want you to even pass it on to your troops yet, because you'll brief them aboard ship.
No need for anybody to know it, except you people.
And so one knucklehead, one officer, he came out.
Subconsciously, he didn't mean to.
He started whistling, the Isle of Capri.
Right over the Isle of Capri.
Kicked him and said, shut up, you fool.
And so we landed in Salerno.
Before we landed, Italy had surrendered.
And so everybody was happy that this was going to be a short campaign, taking Italy out.
But the Italians' heart, if it ever was, wasn't to win the war at all.
They were very poor soldiers in North Africa.
In fact, the Germans usually just ignored them because they knew that they wouldn't fight, wouldn't stand.
not dependable at all.
And in some cases, the Germans claimed they were more of a burden, because they had to supply them and at least make out like, since they're allies, that you told them, yeah, you have this sector.
And so when we went into Italy, of course, the Italians did make a bit of a difference, because the Germans had moved down the Salerno, especially around the hill.
And they were prepared for the landing
Fortunately, I'm a company commander now.
My unit was not.
I wasn't a rifle company commander.
I was a headquarters company commander, captain.
But our battalion wasn't in the assault wing.
So the ones who took the cages were the ones who were assaulting the beach.
So we went on in fairly good shape on up to the high ground
When did you land?
How many days after the original assault?
Same day.
Oh, the same day, but just later?
It just wasn't in the leading way.
Okay.
It was still fire on the beach when we got there, artillery and mortar, but not small army fire.
Always some off at the flank, some on the thing, but not... We went on up to the high ground and got the beach secured, and then the Germans counterattacked.
And they almost got all the way back down to the beach, but a tank unit was able to stop the tank, any tank that knocked out two or three German tanks.
Finally went up to Alta Villa, had that secured, and then the Germans counterattacked and retook that.
What did you think of the German troops in that place, the quality of them?
All good.
Not quite as good as those North African troops.
But still, at this time in the war, the quality was still high.
Later on in France and Germany, it slacked off completely.
Not completely, but quite a bit.
Older men, younger, and they didn't have the heart.
They knew the war was lost.
How did the Italian civilians, how did your troops get along with them?
every village you go, they got cousins in New York City and Chicago.
Oh yeah, Americans and Italians, I really like Italians.
They love to sing and eat and have sex.
So many of them, I guess they do.
But the action
So much of my life has been luck.
The next action was that the Germans were attacking the perimeter, and the high command, General Clark, decided that a regiment of the 45th Division, that's the Oklahoma unit, would be pulled out.
This is an entire regiment now, between the Salay and the Kolo River, would be pulled out.
in our battalion who were replaced.
And it was a night exercise.
So you could hear it.
And they had tanks and tank destroyers supporting them.
We did.
So here at night, you could hear that clanking of the tanks.
All of them were going in a different direction.
And nothing but quietness.
That's what we were seeing.
And it got real quiet.
And our troops were digging in.
Early the next day, the Germans attacked.
They attacked us from the front and they attacked us from the flank.
And Colonel Jones, Lieutenant Colonel, who commanded the battalion, we had no communication with divisions.
All the lines were out.
Radios couldn't contact us.
We were beyond artillery range.
All the things that you're teaching, you never let this happen.
Sure.
You've got to have them in support.
Right.
Support.
So you were like on a peninsula.
Yeah, I was about to.
Because you have two.
But Germans on both sides.
Two streams.
You've got the Germans in front.
We've got these two rivers.
But you've got the Germans.
One is shallow enough for them to cross.
And then there's a road that goes on back behind.
So since I was the headquarters company commander, this is why I say I had a lot of lucky breaks.
Colonel Jones, he said, Captain Andrew, you go back to division and you tell them what our situation is.
And we need assistance.
We can't get artillery support.
And you can hear these German tanks around here.
And you can already hear machine guns.
The German machine guns, of course, were rapid.
You ever heard everybody and machine like that.
So I said, Yes, sir.
So we took off with my jeep with my driver who happened to be in Caldwell heading back to division.
Well, when we got back near a crossing, the German tank and infantry you could see him was already almost completely surrounding the battalion.
But we were able to scoot through that, not on the road, but got across on a, it wasn't a bridge, but it was a field, sort of like a low-crossing bridge that the jeep could get across.
We cut out across an open field and got away from the Germans.
Did they see you?
Yeah, because they were shooting small arms, not artillery, just about some jeep going across the field, plowed field.
And they were shooting at you?
And I saw, yeah, but not, this is not the dangerous part.
It comes a little bit later.
So I saw a man running the line, I guess coming out to our battalion, you know.
And I got down and I said, you have contact with the division?
He said, yes, sir.
So he plugged in his telephone and sounded.
And I got the G3 of the division.
And I told him that Jones had sent me out.
They need help.
They're practically surrounded now.
And I say, they are surrounded now.
I said, you couldn't be, because I said, you up there, it's the lake over there.
And I said, please, take my word for it.
He said, I just got shot at.
I can see the Germans right now.
And he says, all right, I'll do what I can.
So then we started back, thinking we'd go around and get back to them.
But then they had got complete crossing.
Not quite encircled yet, because there's still one access way around.
It'd have to be at Alapavilla.
As I was trying to work away, the Germans had outdeveloped.
They worked their way back around to get back to Jones, although all we could do is give them sympathy and say the message was conveyed.
German 88 millimeter, that's a combination ground, mountain, any aircraft.
